posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: We’re plugging our pololu voltage regulator into an MPM and I was wondering what fuse to use on it, does it matter?

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
In general:

The fuse protects the wire.

So what size wire do you have feeding the regulator from the MPM?

Then look up the Max size fuse FIRST allows on that size wire gauge in the rule book and your good-to-go.

Also avoid the absurd ;p if you are using 18awg to the MPM and 2 awg between the MPM and the regulator…it is illegocial to have a 10A fuse protecting the MPM wiring from your PDP / PDH , then a 40A or whatever the largest fuse the MPM will accept protecting the 2awg between MPM and regulator…it will never blow and the upstream 10A in the PDP / PDH will always be the one blowing. So your fuse sizes should be cascading DOWN in size the farther down the branch circuit you go.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked:
If your Pololu converter is powering something like an Orange Pi, the wire between the converter and the Pi must also be protected and it falls under R622 since it’s your wire and not wire integral to the device from the manufacturer.

If you happen to have a D36V50F5 and can only get 22awg wire in the tiny holes, you could use a 10A fuse.  However, if on the output side of the converter you have a USB-C pigtail or are wiring to the GPIO pins with Dupont-socketed wire, and that wire is only 24awg or maybe less, the 10A fuse becomes too big.

Make sure all your wire downstream of the fuse is at least the minimum size for the fuse rating.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
paulonis:

the Pi must also be protected and it falls under R622 since it’s your wire and not wire integral to the device from the manufacturer.

R622 is there to make sure appropriate sized wire is used within a protected circuit. The additional information below the table:

Wires that are recommended by the device manufacturer or originally attached to legal devices are considered part of the device and by default legal. Such wires are exempt from this rule, provided they are powered by the smallest value fuse or breaker which permits proper device operation.

Serves to exempt wiring attached to the device or recommended for use by the manufacturer from the tables sizing requirements - but I don’t read that as requiring the wiring used downstream of a voltage regulator (or other custom circuit with team-not- COTS -wiring), to need fuse/circuit breaker protection.

Would wiring off a VRM then need additional downstream protection before reaching the powered device? (edit: this is explicitly allowed by the table 8.4?)

R621 deals with protecting circuits with appropriate sized circuit breakers/fuses. The blue box language is particularly illuminating, I think pointing out that additional downstream fuses/breakers from the PDP / PDH /PDP2.0 are not prohibited, but also not explicitly required.

This rule does not prohibit the use of smaller value breakers in the PDP /PDP2.0/ PDH or any fuses or breakers within CUSTOM CIRCUITS for additional protection. Fans permitted per R501 may also be included within CUSTOM CIRCUITS.

I’m going to take a bit longer to think about this before editing/responding and adding more because I do see some loopholes here unless covered by another rule I’m not seeing.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: So if i’m reading this right then we can use a 10 amp fuse because we have 18awg going to the regulator even though the output is the small wires in a spark max usb cable?

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I think there is likely a rules-hole or I am misinterpreting the rule. From my current rule-reading I think for 18AWG wire an up-to 20A circuit protection device as the output from the PDP / PDH /PDP2.0 is technically the only required circuit protection device…but I’m taking more time thinking through the intent and physics of failure.

Adding a fuse to the output of the DC-DC for the smaller gauge wire in a USB-C pigtail would not be AGAINST the rules and would provide more protection for more of the wires in the custom circuit…but I dont know that its explicitly required and I’m thinking it should be but I’m not seeing where in the rules that’s stated?

What exact DC-DC voltage regulator are you using? What is its max rated current/power output?

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Output voltage
		Typical max output current1
		Input voltage range2
	
	
		5 V
		 5.5 A
		 5.5 V – 50 V
	

Note 1: Typical continuous output current at 36 V in. Actual achievable continuous output current is a...

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
I think I’m confusing myself with a bunch of FRC rules lawyering in mind.

Recommendation: stick with the general principal: the fuse protects the wire.

I think I agree with @paulonis ultimately, with some additional context.

If you use a 10A fuse in the PDP / PDH /PDP2.0 that will protect the 18AWG distribution wire to the DC-DC.

The output of the DC-DC is technically protected by its upstream fuse or by the DC-DC itself by its funciton/nature…it can only put out soo much current before saturating and its output collapsing - but…a 10A fuse on the input side of the DC-DC doesn’t mean it will blow if the output of the DC-DC is 10A if the output voltage is LOWER. We need to go to POWER and convert:

V=IxR P=VxI

So a 10A fuse on the 12V distribution bus of the PDP / PDH /PDP2.0 will allow nominally 120W

Then the output of your DC-DC is 5V, so solving for I in P=VxI means 120=5xI…I=24A

So that upstream 10A fuse wont blow until the output of the DC-DC is pulling more than 24A at 5V DC.

Since your selected DC-DC is rated for 5.5A continuous (it could and will supply more for a shorter amount of time up to a limit…that limit or short circuit output current is not listed on the specs page for the device however…lets assume its 10A for this analysis) - that means your downstream wiring is essentially got a free circuit protection device at 10A.  This puts you at needing an 18AWG >=22AWG (per @paulonis and table 8.4 R622), wire on the output with no additional circuit protection.

Edit: See later reply for a convergent recommendation that happens to be the same last sentence in the above paragraph.

To be safe I would wire the output with 18AWG or if using it with a smaller wire gauge downstream ensuring that wiring complies with R622 - in the case of 24AWG then using an additional 2A fuse or circuit breaker on the output of the DC-DC to protect that downstream 24AWG wire.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: A Pololu D36V50F5 can deliver 8A at 5V from a 12V supply.  It comes as a board with no wires attached.  The end-user supplies input and output wire.  I don’t see how it can be legal to put this on a 20A fused circuit because you supplied 18awg input wires, regardless of the fact that you might have 26awg wire in a USB cable on the output.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Table 8.4 allows up to 20A circuit protection device for 18AWG wire.

Personally I don’t like 18AWG for a circuit pulling 20A, I like 18AWG for circuits 10A and lower but I’m dealing with non- FRC use-case (continuous operation for many hours whereas FRC is 3min. or so).

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
Jwal:

using an additional 2A fuse or circuit breaker on the output of the DC-DC to protect that downstream 24AWG wire.

the orange pi requires 4A

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Edit: See below replies for a converged and cleaner recommendation by @paulonis

Original:

That is indeed a concern!

Perhaps in this case the text below the 8.4 table in R622 is more applicable than I thought with some rules-lawyering:

Wires that are recommended by the device manufacturer or originally attached to legal devices are considered part of the device and by default legal. Such wires are exempt from this rule, provided they are powered by the smallest value fuse or breaker which permits proper device operation.

The argument being that the Orange Pi uses a USB-C input implying the use of any COTS USB-C cable is “recommended” by the manufacturer.

Those USB-C cables contain as low as 24AWG wire. So that is logically “recommended” by the manufacturer.

Then…by rule you must power the device with the smallest value fuse/breaker which permits proper device operation:

5V@4A means a 4A fuse/breaker on the output of the DC-DC…or a 2A fuse/breaker at the MPM on the 12V side powering the DC-DC as that is the smallest size fuse that will allow >20W (5Vx4A=20W, 12Vx2A=24W), needed by the OrangePi.

posts.name: paulonis
posts.cooked: For Orange Pi power, my recommendation is to use a USB-C power pigtail with wires >= 22awg ( example with 20awg ) on the output of the converter, use >= 22awg wires on the input side of the converter, and use a 10A fuse in the MPM.  This setup definitely complies with R622.  YMMV if an inspector will pass you if you have unknown gauge wire (and likely <= 24awg) inside a USB cable from the converter to the Pi and have the circuit on a 10A fuse.

posts.name: Joseph Walters
posts.cooked:
Duh: I skipped over the 22AWG wire section and noting the table specifies MINIMUM wire size (so if you can find 20AWG that could also be protected by a 10A fuse…)

So I agree with @paulonis for this particular custom circuit. Choose >= 22AWG wire for the input and output, and a 10A fuse or 5A breaker or lower.

Others who may be using different DC-DC converters may have different needs, i.e. a higher power DC-DC .

That particular device can supply 15A on its output, so it would need a 20A fuse and 18AWG wire on its output, even if it were supplied with 20AWG and a 10A fuse on the input…which I wouldn’t recommend due to voltage drop but it would be rule compliant.
